message.content:
cs.GT, cs.DS, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.EC. 

The paper deals with fair allocation of goods, which is a classic problem in game theory and economics. The use of the maxmin share paradigm and the focus on approximation algorithms suggest that the paper belongs to the cs.GT (Game Theory) sub-category. The clustering approach and the use of techniques such as reducibility, matching allocation, and cycle-envy-freeness suggest that the paper also belongs to the cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) sub-category. The extension of the results to submodular, fractionally subadditive, and subadditive settings suggests that the paper also belongs to the cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) and cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-categories. Finally, the focus on fair allocation and approximation algorithms suggests that the paper also belongs to the cs.EC (Economics and Computation) sub-category.
